content: Luther J. Rollins Jr., a Missouri/Illinois-licensed attorney, likely committed unlicensed practice of law (UPL) under Florida Statutes § 454.23 by drafting a custom lease extension for Florida property while not licensed in Florida. The act was performed from North Carolina and affects Florida tenants, falling under Florida’s jurisdictional reach for UPL violations.

Key precedents:
- Keyes Co. v. Dade County Bar Ass'n (1950): Establishes that drafting real estate documents including leases constitutes the practice of law unless within statutory exceptions.
- The Florida Bar re: Advisory Opinion – Nonlawyer Preparation of Residential Leases (1996): Only Supreme Court-approved leases of under one year can be completed by nonlawyers under strict limitations.
- The Florida Bar v. Moses (1980): Practice of law is defined by effect, not location. Luther’s conduct falls squarely within this rule.
